Manx: Nish eginit dy aagail yn traih,
English: Now compelled to leave the shore,
Diplomatic: Nish eginyt dy aagail yn traih

Manx: Raad ta my chomraagyn ec shee,
English: Where my companions are at peace.
Diplomatic: Raad ta my comraagyn eck shee

Manx: Fegooish monney caarjyn, ny graih,
English: Without many friends, or love,
Diplomatic: Fegooish monney charjyn ny ghraih

Manx: Ny ainjysee gerjagh my chree.
English: Or acquaintances consoling my heart.
Diplomatic: Ny ainjeeesy gherjagh my chree

Manx: Nish faagail yn Ellan my chooyl,
English: Now leaving the Island behind me,
Diplomatic: Nish faagail yn Ellan my chooyl

Manx: Raad cheau mee lane bleeantyn dy eash,
English: Where I spent many years of age,
Diplomatic: Raad cheau mee lane bleeintyn dy eash

Manx: Ayns sleityn as glionteenyn shooyl,
English: Walking in mountains and glens,
Diplomatic: Ayns seityn as lhonteeyn shooyl

Manx: As croink ta mygeayrt ec Creneash.
English: And hills that Cregneash have around.
Diplomatic: As croink ta mygeayrt eck crenaish

Manx: Ny pusheeyn s’aalin va gaase,
English: The most beautiful flowers were growing,
Diplomatic: Ny pusheeyn s’aalin va gaase

Manx: As thammagyn aittyn as freoagh,
English: And bushes of gorse and heather;
Diplomatic: As thammagyn ashyn as frigh

Manx: Veagh ad broo son foddyr da’n vaase.
English: They would press for fodder for the livestock.
Diplomatic: Vagh ad broo son foddyr d’an maase

Manx: Syn niarragh veagh maghyryn glass,
English: In the Spring green fields would,
Diplomatic: Syn niarragh vagh maghyryn glass

Manx: Ayns garmodyn geayney soilshean,
English: Shine in emerald clothes,
Diplomatic: Ayn garmodyn yeney soljean

Manx: Tra veagh Ree yn Laa jannoo çhiass,
English: When the King of the Day (‘Sun’) would make heat,
Diplomatic: Tra vagh Ree yn Laa janoo chass

Manx: As moiraghyn roie mârish e heayin
English: And mothers run with her lambs.*
Diplomatic: As moiraghyn roie maarish yheay

Manx: Lane gerjagh veagh reddyn myr shen,
English: Things like that used to bring to me,
Diplomatic: Lane gherjagh vagh reddyn myr shen

Manx: Ayns laghyn my aegid, cur dou,
English: Much happiness in the days of my youth,
Diplomatic: Ayns laghyn my aagid cur dou

Manx: Tra veagh yn raad çhirrym as glen,
English: When the way used to be dry and clean,
Diplomatic: Tra vagh yn raaid chyrrym as glen

Manx: Yn sniaghtey as rio ersooyl roo.
English: The snow and ice gone on their way.
Diplomatic: Yn snaghtey as rio er sooyl roue

Manx: Agh nish ta mee eginit dy gholl,
English: But now I am compelled to go,
Diplomatic: Agh nish ta mee eginyt dy ghool

Manx: Harrish yn vooir mooar ta cha lhean
English: Over the great sea, that is so broad,
Diplomatic: Harrish yn muir mooar ta cha lheay

Manx: Gys çheer nagh vel aym eer oayl.
English: To a country that I don’t even know.
Diplomatic: Gys cheer nagh vell aym irree oayl

Manx: Gyn fakin yn aarkey soilshean,
English: Without seeing the ocean shining,
Diplomatic: Gyn fakin yn aarkey soljean

Manx: My laghyn dy leah vees ec kione,
English: My days soon will be ended,
Diplomatic: My laghyn dy leah vess eck kione

Manx: Son ta mee gaase shen t’eh feer phlean,
English: For I am growing old, it is very plain,
Diplomatic: Son ta mee gaas shen te feer flean

Manx: Tra gerrid as eisht cha beem ayn.
English: A short time, and then I won’t exist.
Diplomatic: Tra gherryd as esht cha beem ayn

Manx: O Vannin, yn boayl va mee ruggit,
English: O Mannin, the place I was born,
Diplomatic: O Vannin yn boayl va mee ruggyt

Manx: Yn çheer jeh my aegid as eash,
English: The country of my youth and (old) age,
Diplomatic: Yn cheer jeh my aagid as aish

Manx: As ny croink ghoo raad va mee troggit
English: And the black hills where I was raised,
Diplomatic: As ny croink dhoo raad va mee throggyt

Manx: Ny sleityn as croink mysh Creneash
English: The mountains and hills about Cregneash.
Diplomatic: Ny sleityn as crionk mysh crenaish

Manx: As nish bee yn niarragh reesht,
English: And now the Spring will be back,
Diplomatic: As nish bee yn niarragh reesht

Manx: Yn ghrian bee goaill toshiaght lesh bree,
English: The sun will be starting up energetically,
Diplomatic: Yn ghrain bee ghoaill toshagh lesh bree

Manx: Slane lhiat son dy bragh Skylley Chreest.
English: Farewell forever Rushen Parish.
Diplomatic: Slane lhat son dy braagh skilley Chreest

Manx: My vees yms agh faagit ec shee,
English: If I am only left at peace,
Diplomatic: Myr vees yms agh faagyt eck shee

Manx: Fud joareeyn nish ceau my hraa,
English: Amongst foreigners now spending my time,
Diplomatic: Fud joareeyn nish cheau my chra

Manx: Gyn ainjys er peiagh erbee,
English: No acquaintance with anyone,
Diplomatic: Gyn ainjys er piagh erbee

Manx: Ny lomarcan rouaill dagh laa.
English: Alone, wandering every day.
Diplomatic: Ny lomyrken rouaill dagh laa

Manx: Agh shen ta nish gerjagh my chree,
English: But that which now gladdens my heart,
Diplomatic: Agh shen ta nish gherjagh my chree

Manx: Nish foddey voish Mannin ta mish,
English: Now far from Mannin am I,
Diplomatic: Nish foddey voish Mannin ta mish

Manx: Yn boayl ta my chaarjyn ny lhie,
English: The place (where) my friends lie,
Diplomatic: Un boayl ta my charjyn ny lhie

Manx: As my chree boght ta guint as brisht,
English: And my poor heart that is wounded and broken,
Diplomatic: As my chree bogh ta guint as brish

Manx: Dy leah vees ec fea kiart cha mie.
English: Will soon be resting just as well.
Diplomatic: Dy lheah vess eck fea chart cha mie

Manx: Jerkal dy vel shiu ayns slaynt, ta mee cur seose dy screeu ny smoo ec yn traa shoh.
English: Expecting (hoping) that you are in health, I am giving up writing more at this time.
Diplomatic: jerkal dy vell shiu ayns slaynt “ta mee cur seose dy scrieu ny smoo Eck yn tra shoh.

Manx: Ta mee tannaghtyn nyn sharvaant biallagh,
English: I remain your obedient servant,
Diplomatic: Ta mee tannaghtyn Nyn sharvaant bialagh

Manx: Edward Faragher
English: Edward Faragher
Diplomatic: Edward Faragher
